text: Hey all, who are your favorite thought leaders in the content marketing space at the moment? Anyone you’d recommend to follow on Twitter or LinkedIn for fresh perspective?

elements.text: Hey all, who are your favorite thought leaders in the content marketing space at the moment? Anyone you’d recommend to follow on Twitter or LinkedIn for fresh perspective?

text: I love Ann Handley (in particular, her newsletter Total Annarchy). One of our go-to freelancers, Chris Gillespie, also shares some great content (and has a great newsletter).

elements.text: I love Ann Handley (in particular, her newsletter Total Annarchy). One of our go-to freelancers, Chris Gillespie, also shares some great content (and has a great newsletter).

Besides the Animalz crew, I like Robbie Richards (blend of SEO & content marketing) + MarketMuse has been putting out some interesting things lately

And Chris Von Wilpert (content mavericks)

text: Hi frands! Any favorite writing resources/tutorials to help train non-marketers? In this particular case, I’m looking to help customer success managers improve their writing skills.

elements.text: Hi frands! Any favorite writing resources/tutorials to help train non-marketers? In this particular case, I’m looking to help customer success managers improve their writing skills.

text: Hemingway is a great free app that that shows you what's wrong with your writing - I recommend it to a lot of folks who are struggling with their writing <http://www.hemingwayapp.com/>

text:
I’d highly recommend giving them copies of On Writing Well - William Zinsser. One of the best books on writing no matter what kind of writer you are. I wrote about a few more books on writing here: <https://santiagos.space/best-books-on-writing|https://santiagos.space/best-books-on-writing>

I also wrote this other post that distilled some of my experiences of trying to improve my writing. Might be helpful also. - <https://santiagos.space/how-to-become-better-writer|https://santiagos.space/how-to-become-better-writer>

Also, <@URWLPUJ7N> has some good stuff on his website: <https://colliermarketing.com/blog/|https://colliermarketing.com/blog/>

attachments.title: Best Books on Writing to Improve Your Craft Today | Jon Santiago
attachments.text: Writing may be a solitary effort, but we’re not alone in the struggle. Take advice from fellow scribes who’ve authored some of the best books on writing.
attachments.fallback: Jon Santiago: Best Books on Writing to Improve Your Craft Today | Jon Santiago

elements.text: Thanks for the tag
This post seems to be the one people say they have gotten the most out of and should be helpful to anyone—pro writer or not.

text: Grammarly is my main tool, does Hemingway do something different?

elements.text: Grammarly is my main tool, does Hemingway do something different?

text: Thanks <@USDJZRL7N> + <@URWLPUJ7N>!

elements.text: Thanks

text: I haven't used Grammarly much because I found it very glitchy with my work email, but Hemingway is not a browser extension. It's a free in-browser editor/paid desktop editor that you copy and paste text into.

elements.text: I haven't used Grammarly much because I found it very glitchy with my work email, but Hemingway is not a browser extension. It's a free in-browser editor/paid desktop editor that you copy and paste text into.

text: Grammarly has a desktop editor (and extension)

elements.text: Grammarly has a desktop editor (and extension)

text: Grammarly is probably smarter.

elements.text: Grammarly is probably smarter.

text: Hemingway is just fast and easy cuz you don't need an account.

elements.text: Hemingway is just fast and easy cuz you don't need an account.

text:
I use them for different things.

Hemingway is a less advanced tool than Grammarly, but I find it much easier to use to get a look at readability. There is a desktop version but I just use the web version, which seems like it’s the exact same thing. I shoot for around grade 6. Anything above grade 9 I try to bring down by chopping sentences in half, shortening paragraphs, or cutting long words that I could replace with shorter ones. The way Hemingway highlights the text makes it really easy to make edits like that.

I use Grammarly for the pure grammar stuff. I have the pro account and the desktop editor. I don’t have the extension turned on because it kept annoying me for stuff I knew I didn’t want to change when I was loading article into Wordpress. The pro version marks a lot more than the free web version. I often don’t make the recommended changes, but I really like that it marks stuff for me to review. It means I get to make a choice about how I really want things to be.

My final step is to have my computer read the piece back to me in my headphones. On a Mac it’s built in, but there are web applications that can do the same thing if you’re on a PC.

So my proofreading workflow is Hemingway > Grammarly > Listen to the piece.

I hope that’s helpful. I’ve been doing this on anything I write for a couple of years now and find it to be really helpful. At the very least, it catches _almost_ all my typos, which used to plague me in my earlier days. :)

elements.text:
I use them for different things.

Hemingway is a less advanced tool than Grammarly, but I find it much easier to use to get a look at readability. There is a desktop version but I just use the web version, which seems like it’s the exact same thing. I shoot for around grade 6. Anything above grade 9 I try to bring down by chopping sentences in half, shortening paragraphs, or cutting long words that I could replace with shorter ones. The way Hemingway highlights the text makes it really easy to make edits like that.

I use Grammarly for the pure grammar stuff. I have the pro account and the desktop editor. I don’t have the extension turned on because it kept annoying me for stuff I knew I didn’t want to change when I was loading article into Wordpress. The pro version marks a lot more than the free web version. I often don’t make the recommended changes, but I really like that it marks stuff for me to review. It means I get to make a choice about how I really want things to be.

My final step is to have my computer read the piece back to me in my headphones. On a Mac it’s built in, but there are web applications that can do the same thing if you’re on a PC.

So my proofreading workflow is Hemingway > Grammarly > Listen to the piece.

I hope that’s helpful. I’ve been doing this on anything I write for a couple of years now and find it to be really helpful. At the very least, it catches
almost
all my typos, which used to plague me in my earlier days. :)
